instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-0045: What is 820-0045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H? This is the input from the USB-C charger or the battery that is the input voltage for the chip responsible for creating PP3V3_G3H. It can be missing when capacitors on this line are shorted to ground, or when the diode in front of it leading to the chip that creates PP3V3_G3H is blown. .
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
Board from another shop.

Tested with board only and genuine 87W USB-C charger.
Sometimes it there is spike and consume 0.05A


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 8.60V
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V3G3H</SIGNAL> - 20.1V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 8.61V
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_E85</SIGNAL> - 20.1V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.30V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> - 3.26V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.29V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H_LDO</SIGNAL> - 5.0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 5.0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.0V got every a few sec there is spike to around 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.30V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.30V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 0.350V (spike to 3.30V every a few seconds)
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.0V

I checked and <CHIP>U8990</CHIP> has been replaced by other shop so I replaced it one more time just in case but still same issue.

As got small experience with <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> I am lost nowâ€¦

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20V 0A
threads.message:
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> is the worst MacBook ever made by Apple.
And <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> is the worst of the worst.
All these end with dead CPU.

I really do NOT recommend to waste time on this, more even if was already touched in other service shop.

"<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 0.0V got every a few sec there is spike to around 5V"
Then <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> should spike too; check diode mode there.
Also check for short on all big coils.
